physicalObject: white VR controller with black circular top and braided strap
explanation: The controller’s grip diameter matches a small hammer handle, and the black top is slightly heavier than the rest, but the entire unit is very light plastic (~100 g). The mass does not pull the wrist downward during swings, so the head-heavy moment and overall momentum feel noticeably under-scaled.

When gripped by one corner, most of the keyboard’s ~800 g mass hangs forward, creating a real head-heavy bias that the wrist must counter. However the ‘handle’ is only a thin edge, not a 30–40 cm cylindrical shaft, so leverage control is awkward and the center of rotation is too close to the mass. Provides correct heaviness but wrong geometry.

The sleeve is soft and very light; once suspended, it flops rather than creating a firm, momentum-rich swing. No significant mass concentration exists, so the expected downward torque from a hammer head is almost absent.
A single sheet has negligible weight; during a swing it offers virtually zero inertia and no perceivable head-heaviness, leading to a jarringly unrealistic experience compared to a hammer.

Although heavier than paper, the mouse pad is still light and flexible. Pinching a corner provides little rigidity and only a mild sense of weight, so momentum and impact feel far weaker than a true hammer.

The mug’s ceramic body supplies decent mass (~300 g) located away from the small handle, giving a clear head-heavy feel. However the lever arm is very short (handle length ~5 cm), so the rotational inertia and swing dynamics fall short of a 40 cm hammer handle.

physicalObject: white VR controller with black circular top
explanation: The grip section is a smooth, quasi-cylindrical tube about the right diameter for a fist wrap, allowing a power-grip similar to a hammer handle. Length is much shorter (~12-15 cm vs 40 cm) and the head is plastic and only slightly heavier than the handle, so lever feel and head bias are weak, but the basic outline of a straight handle terminating in a flat disc is present.

Clamping a rectangular keyboard edge gives no cylindrical surface; the user ends up pinching a thin, sharp edge rather than wrapping fingers around a round shaft. Mass distribution (large flat plate) also feels nothing like a narrow handle with a compact head.
The sleeve is floppy and has no rigid handle at all. There is no cylindrical structure to grasp, so the outline cues of a hammer handle are completely absent.
A thin sheet offers no volume for a fist-grip and no rigid rod shape, so the user cannot experience the expected cylindrical handle outline.
The mouse pad is a flexible, flat mat; any corner pinch provides no cylindrical form. Outline feedback of a solid round handle is entirely missing.

The mug does supply a heavy head, but the user grips a narrow curved handle with fingers through a loop rather than wrapping around a straight 3–4 cm cylinder. The outline in hand therefore only partially matches the expected hammer handle.
